New Records: This is the first away victory in the Nations League for Ireland since the competition began six years ago.
This is the first time Ireland have fought back from conceding first to win a competitive game since beating Kazakhstan in October 2013.
Key Match Events: Liam Scales scored his first goal in green, cancelling out Joel Pohjanpalo’s opener in the first half.
Festy Ebosele provided a stunning assist for Robbie Brady’s 88th-minute winner, which was his first assist for Ireland.
Evan Ferguson had a disallowed goal when a free kick from Brady went out of play and couldn’t be kept in by Collins.
Pre-Game Insights: Heimir Hallgrímsson, the Republic of Ireland manager, has spoken about the need to'stop the bleeding' and has a new message and different demands for the players.
The team's game plan was to lure Finland out close to the defensive third and then win possession to counter in the areas left exposed by a pair of full backs who ventured forward.
Post-Match Reflections: Hallgrímsson praised the team's performance and said it was a precious win that keeps Ireland off the bottom of Group 2 in League B.
The win was a testament to the new message and belief in what Hallgrímsson can do, and it gives the team new momentum going into their next away clash in Greece.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The attendance at the Olympic Stadium in Helsinki was 16,105.
The match was a Nordic exploration for the Republic of Ireland, and they faced a similarly beleaguered team in Finland that lacked in confidence.
Others: The man in the front row of the away end with his right arm in a sling was a symbol of the team's struggles, but he was seen celebrating wildly when Robbie Brady scored the winning goal.
